revision.text:
{{about|a specific Buddhist organization|the form of Buddhism sometimes called "Diamond Way Buddhism"|Vajrayana}}
{{Primary sources|date=December 2009}}
{{Buddhism}} '''Diamond Way Buddhism''' (''Diamond Way Buddhism - Karma Kagyu Lineage'') is a [[Laity|lay]] organization within the [[Karma Kagyu]] school of [[Tibetan Buddhism]]. The first Diamond Way Buddhist centre was founded in 1972 by Hannah and [[Ole Nydahl]]. It is led by Ole Nydahl under the spiritual guidance of [[Trinley Thaye Dorje]], one of two claimants to the title of the [[17th Karmapa]] (''See [[Karmapa Controversy]])''. There are approximately 650 Diamond Way Buddhist centres world wide.
==History and development== Following the Chinese invasion of Tibet in 1950, and the subsequent self-exile of the Dalai Lama to India in 1959, thousands of Tibetans fled Chinese-occupied Tibet as refugees, creating the [[Tibetan diaspora]]. The head of [[Karma Kagyu]] school, [[Rangjung Rigpe Dorje]], the 16th Karmapa, also left Tibet in 1959 and established [[Rumtek monastery]] in [[Sikkim]], India as his main seat in exile. The exodus of Tibetans ultimately made [[Tibetan Buddhism]] more accessible to the rest of the world. Many young Westerners on the [[hippie trail]] from Europe to India and Nepal came in contact with the Tibetans and some became interested in their religion. Among these first Westerners to come into contact with the Tibetans in exile were Hannah and Ole Nydahl, who went on their [[honeymoon]] to the [[Himalayas]]. They first became students of [[Lopon Tsechu Rinpoche]]. In 1969 they met the [[Rangjung Rigpe Dorje|16th Karmapa]] and became his closest Western students. After meditating and studying Buddhism for three years, the 16th Karmapa asked Ole and Hannah to start meditation centres in his name in the [[West]].<ref name="ENTER">Nydahl, Ole "Entering The Diamond Way, Tibetan Buddhism Meets the West", Blue Dolphin Publishing (1999). ISBN 978-0-931892-03-5</ref><ref name="CUR">Curren, Erik D. (2008) ''Buddha's Not Smiling, Uncovering the Corruption at the Heart of Tibetan Buddhism Today'' Alaya Press ISBN 0-9772253-0-5</ref> The first Karma Kagyu center in the West was founded in 1972 in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]].<ref name="ENTER"/>
In 1973 the 16th Karmapa visited Europe at the invitation of Ole and Hannah Nydahl.<ref name="TIGER">Nydahl, Ole (1992) ''Riding The Tiger, Twenty Years on the Road - The Risks and Joys of Bringing Tibetan Buddhism to the West'', Blue Dolphin Publishing. ISBN 978-0-931892-67-7</ref><ref name="KHIS">[http://www.karmapa.org/history/karmapa_16/index.htm Karmapa.org website] Retrieved 2009-02-12</ref> Following this visit and at the 16th Karmapa's request, Ole Nydahl began travelling further across Europe in order to teach the basic doctrines of [[Karma Kagyu]] [[Buddhism]]. As more became interested more centers were founded and their number increased over time, particularly in [[Germany]] and [[Poland]]. The individual groups grew steadily.<ref name="TIGER"/> He later travelled to the [[United States]] and across [[South America]] and [[Russia]], founding more centres.
Following the [[Karmapa Controversy]], Karma Kagyu Buddhist centres were obliged to decide whether to accept Orgyen Trinley Dorje, who was recognised by Tai Situ, the Dalai Lama and the Chinese government, or to support Shamar Rinpoche. In the course of the 1990s, while a majority of Kagyu monasteries elected to accept Orgyen Trinley Dorje, most Diamond Way centres under Ole Nydahl accepted Thaye Dorje.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lehnert|first=Tomek|title=Rogues in Robes: An Inside Chronicle of a Chinese-Tibetan Intrigue in the Karma Kagyu Lineage of Diamond Way Buddhism|year=2000|publisher=Blue Dolphin Publishing|isbn=1-57733-026-9}}</ref> <ref name="OLE98">[http://www.diamondway-teachings.org/export/en/content/olenydahl/bt4ole.html 1998 Interview with Ole Nydahl] Retrieved on 2009-30-01</ref>
[[File:diamondwaymap.png|thumb|Centres of the ''Diamond Way Buddhism'' January 2009.]]
Diamond Way Buddhism was founded as a legally distinct organization within the Karma Kagyu umbrella in 1993. Until then, the Nydahls had transferred all ownership of the centers they founded to the Karma Kagyu administration.<ref name="CUR"/> However, it is common for Karma Kagyu lamas to each have their own organization for their students, as each teacher has a different style and approach. For example, [[Shamarpa]] has the Bodhipath organization, [[Chogyam Trungpa]] had the [[Vajradhatu]], etc. The goals of the Diamond Way organization remain "the creation and maintenance of a permanent basis from which to enable both laypeople and achievers to maintain, cultivate and practice Buddhist religion, philosophy and culture in countries that are not originally Buddhist, within the traditional manner of the Diamond Way transmission of the Karma Kagyu lineage", [[Buddhist art]], supporting translations of authentic Buddhist text, and funding retreats etc. The "spiritual counsel" of the organisation is provided by the 17th Karmapa Trinley Thaye Dorje ([[India]]), Kunzing Shamar Rinpoche (India) and [[Jigme Rinpoche]] ([[France]]).<ref name="CHAR">[http://www.buddhismus-stiftung.de/export/sites/global_diamantweg_stiftung/pdf/Satzung/bsd_satzung_en.pdf Buddhism Foundation Diamond Way Charter] Retrieved on 2009-30-01</ref>
==Ideals== Diamond Way describes itself as an adaptation of the Karma Kagyu tradition to Western culture without Tibetan customs and organisational structures.<ref name="SHAM">[http://www.shamarpa.org/teachings/no-need.php ''No Need for Too Much Tradition'', lecture by Shamar Rinpoche, Vienna, September 1993] Retrieved on 2009-30-01</ref>
Ole Nydahl describes Diamond Way as a [[laity|lay]] tradition offering methods for people who have jobs, partners, families and responsibilities. He states "...our work is grown on the basis of friendship and trust... since the Diamond Way teachings aim to bring freedom and independence, it is people who already have those qualities who are generally attracted to our centers."<ref name="OLE98"/> He also says he is keen to avoid what were perceived to be the more exotic or ritualistic aspects of Tibetan Buddhism such as [[Puja (Buddhism)|pujas]] sung in Tibetan with Tibetan musical accompaniment. In 1998 Ole Nydahl stated "I simply don’t want gifted and critical people who discover us to step right into the middle of a puja as has happened so often in the past. They then think they have landed with Catholics or some other sect and we won’t get a second chance to benefit them or their like-minded friends." <ref name="OLE98"/> Instead, most meditation texts (except [[mantra]]s) are translated and used in European languages.<ref name="DUBUK">[http://www.dwbuk.org/buddhism/meditations DWB in UK about meditations] Retrieved on 2009-30-01</ref>
==Practices== {{LayBuddhistPractices}}
The most important practice in Diamond Way Buddhism is considered to be identification with the teacher and following that to try to sustain the [[Mahamudra]] view and bring what is learned in meditation into daily life.<ref name="MAH">Nydahl. Ole. ''The Great Seal - Limitless Space & Joy'.The Mahamudra View of Diamond Way Buddhism” Fire Wheel Publishing, 2004 ISBN 0-9752954-0-3</ref><ref>Video: ''Nydahl, Ole: Meditation'' 1997 ThreeBearsMedia. [http://www.diamondway-teachings.org/export/en/resources/multimedia.html Available online] [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=35W67OwhEck&feature=PlayList&p=8EFEFA1D34CB89DA&index=0 and on Youtube]</ref><ref>Nydahl, Ole (2008) The Way Things are - A living Approach to Buddhism for todays world. O Books. ISBN 978-1-84694-042-2</ref>
Diamond Way Buddhism uses a variety of standard [[Vajrayana]] meditation methods found within the [[Karma Kagyu]] tradition. When the practitioners meet at lectures or for meditation they will typically do the "Guru Yoga meditation", (Skt. Guru yoga, Tib. Lame Naljor) where the practitioner identifies with the enlightened qualities of the teacher in order to develop these qualities. This is then followed by the "Invocation of Black Coat", sung in Tibetan.<ref name="DUBUK"/>
Like other Karma Kagyu practitioners, individuals then usually do a preliminary practice called the ''[[ngöndro]]'', consisting of 111,111 repetitions each of 4 different meditations, as given by the 9th Karmapa.<ref>Karmapa IX, The Mahamudra, Eliminating the Darkness of Ignorance LTWA. ISBN 978-81-85102-13-9</ref> The ''ngöndro'' must be completed before practitioners can move on to other practices. In most cases, following completion of ''ngöndro'', students practice a meditation on the Eighth Karmapa, [[Mikyö Dorje]], called "The Guru Yoga in Four Sessions" (Tibetan ''Tun Shi Lame Naljor'').<ref name="DUBUK"/>
Other practices include a variant of the meditation on ''[[Chenrezig]]'' (Sanskrit ''Avalokiteśvara'') composed by the 12th Century ''[[siddha]]'' [[Thang Tong Gyalpo|Tang Tong Gyalpo]] and the ''[[phowa]]'' (transference of consciousness at the time of death).<ref name="DUBUK"/>
They receive an explanation of the meditations from more experienced members who are authorized to teach in the Diamond Way Buddhist Centers.<ref name="DUBUK"/>
==Teachers== ===The 16th Karmapa=== {{multiple image |width=200 |image1=Karmapa16 3 gross.jpg|caption1=The 16th Karmapa Ranjung Rigpe Dorje |image2=17-Karmapa-Lon.jpg|caption2=The 17th Karmapa Trinley Thaye Dorje }}
{{Main|Rangjung Rigpe Dorje}} The 16th Karmapa Ranjung Rigpe Dorje (1924–1981) was born in [[Dêgê County|Derge]] in eastern Tibet. Karmapa left the [[People's Republic of China]] in 1959, deciding that the [[Dharma]] would be served better outside Communist China. The Karmapas were the first incarnations to start the [[Tulku|tulku-system]] and they are the heads of the Karma Kagyu lineage.
He was the Lama who told the Nydahls to start Karma Kagyu centres in the West and later visited many Karma Kagyu centres, mainly staying in centres founded by the Nydahls or [[Kalu Rinpoche]].<ref name="WANG">[http://www.karmapa-issue.org/politics/brown_response_2.htm Official statement from Lama Karma Wangchuk, International Karma Kagyu Buddhist Organization. 01.07.2004] Retrieved on 2009-02-02</ref> His first visit in the West was in 1974<ref name="KHIS"/> and he gave numerous teachings and empowerments in the centres.<ref name="CUR"/><ref name="TIGER"/>
===The 17th Karmapa=== {{Main|Trinley Thaye Dorje}} Trinley Thaye Dorje (born 1983) is the current head of the Karma Kagyu School and one of the candidates to the reincarnation of the 16th Karmapa. He is considered the true incarnation of the Karmapa by the Diamond Way Buddhist Centers, as well as by [[Shamarpa]], [[Shangpa Rinpoche]], [[Beru Khyentse Rinpoche]], [[Gyatrul Rinpoche]] and Sherab Gyaltsen Rinpoche.<ref name="DWBT">[http://www.diamondway-buddhism.org/default.asp?col=03&t=teachers.htm DiamondWay-Buddhism.org - Teachers] Retrieved on 2009-02-02</ref>
Trinley Thaye Dorje was born in [[Tibet]] but managed to escape in 1994 and was enthroned by Shamarpa at the [[Karmapa International Buddhist Institute]] (KIBI).<ref name="CUR"/> He has since visited the West several times in order to teach. The first time he visited Europe was in 2000 and the first time he visited the United States was in 2003.<ref name="DWBT"/> {{clear}}
===Ole Nydahl=== [[File:Portrait_of_Lama_Ole_Nydahl_2010.jpg|thumb|right|Lama Ole Nydahl in 2010]] {{Main|Ole Nydahl}} Ole Nydahl (born 1941 near Copenhagen, Denmark), is a Buddhist Lama and one of the main figures in the spreading of Karma Kagyu Buddhism in the West.<ref name="WANG"/><ref name="BORUP">[http://www.globalbuddhism.org/9/borup08.htm Journal of Global Buddhism, Article by Jørn Borup, Department of Study of Religion at University of Aarhus, Denmark. 2008, based on research from 2005] Retrieved on 2009-02-02</ref> Since the early 1970s he has toured the world, giving lectures and meditation courses, and together with his wife Hannah Nydahl (1946–2007) founded Diamond Way Buddhism. He is often referred to as Lama Ole Nydahl or Lama Ole.
===Hannah Nydahl=== {{multiple image |direction=vertical |width=200 |image2=Hannah Nydahl.jpg|caption2=Hannah Nydahl }} '''Hannah Nydahl''' (1946–2007), wife of Ole Nydahl, was an important [[Denmark|Danish]] teacher and translator in the [[Kagyu|Karma Kagyu]] lineage of [[Tibetan Buddhism]].<ref name="TIGER"/> She was born and died in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]].
She and Ole Nydahl were introduced to [[Buddhism]] on their [[honeymoon]] in [[Nepal]] in 1968. They were childhood friends, meeting for the first time when Hannah was 5 and Ole 10.<ref name="ENTER"/> After a three year period of study they were sent back to Europe by the [[16th Karmapa]] to found centres in his name.<ref name="ENTER"/><ref name="CUR"/><ref name="BORUP"/>
She was a Buddhist teacher like her husband (sometimes referred to as ''Lamini'' or ''female Lama''<ref name="MOD">Movie: ''Buddhism in the Modern World'' (2008), Soulproduction</ref>), but the main role of Hannah Nydahl was as a translator for Lamas like the [[16th Karmapa]],<ref name="WANG"/> [[Lopon Tsechu Rinpoche]], [[Kalu Rinpoche]] etc.<ref name="TIGER"/> In an interview she explained, "I do not mind teaching but when I am together with Ole it is more natural that he teaches. When I am not with him I mainly translate and organize for the Tibetan lamas."<ref name="HAN95">Interview with Hannah Nydahl, Kagyu Life International, vol. 4, Virginia, July 1995 [http://www.meditationclub.com/hannah.htm Available online]</ref>
In the magazine ''Kagyu Life International'' she was described in this way: "Hannah Nydahl is a much sought after translator and interpreter of Tibetan Buddhist philosophy. She divides her time between translating for the lamas at the Karmapa International Buddhist Institute in New Delhi, India, participating in various Buddhist text translation projects, organizing schedules and visits of high Rinpoches in the lineage, and traveling around the world with Lama Ole."<ref name="HAN95"/>
She spoke [[German language|German]], [[English language|English]] and [[Tibetan language|Tibetan]] fluently. As few Tibetan teachers spoke English, she learned Tibetan, from Tarab Tulku at Copenhagen University. Since all texts were in Tibetan, her work included translating texts <ref name="HAN95"/>, and spoken translation for the teaching Lamas at the [[Karmapa International Buddhist Institute]] in [[New Delhi]], [[India]], participation in various Buddhist text translation projects, as well as organizing and translating lectures for Tibetan Lamas.<ref name="DWBT"/><ref name="LET04">[http://www.karmapa-issue.org/politics/brown_response_4.htm Open letter regarding Karmapa Controversy by karmapa-issue.org, 26.07.2004] Retrieved on 2009-30-01</ref>
She was widely respected for her work, devotion and accomplishments as a Buddhist practitioner.<ref>[http://www.karmapa-news.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Photos/2007/03-Hannah/Announcement0001sm.pdf Official letter from the 17th Karmapa Trinley Thaye Dorje, 2007] Retrieved on 2009-30-01</ref><ref>[http://www.diamondway-buddhism.org/default.asp?col=01&t=hannah.htm Official letter from Ole Nydahl, 2007] Retrieved on 2009-30-01</ref><ref>[http://www.diamondway-buddhism.org/pdf/Jigme_Rinpoche_about_Hannah.pdf Official letter from Jigme Rinpoche, 2007] Retrieved on 2009-30-01</ref> A Danish newspaper even referred to her as the "Mother of Buddhism".<ref>Nanna Schelde, ''Farvel til buddhisternes mor'' (Farewell to the Mother of Buddhism), Kristeligt Dagblad, Denmark, 03. apr 2007 [http://www.kristeligt-dagblad.dk/artikel/2243:--Farvel-til-buddhisternes-mor Available online] ("In danish")</ref> Jørn Borup, Department of Study of Religion at University of Aarhus said: "The most lasting influence on the Buddhist practice scene in Denmark was triggered by Ole and Hannah Nydahl backpacking in the spiritual East during their honeymoon in Nepal in 1968."<ref name="BORUP"/>
===Shamarpa===
{{Main|Shamarpa}} Kunzig Shamar Rinpoche, born 1952 in Derge, Tibet, is second to the Gyalwa Karmapa in the spiritual hierarchy of the Karma Kagyu School. He fled Tibet at the age of 9 with the 16th Karmapa. Shamarpa is also known as Red Hat Karmapa, and is, together with the 17th Karmapa, the current holder of the Karma Kagyu lineage. Shamarpa completed the Karmapa International Buddhist Institute (KIBI) in [[New Delhi]], India, after the death of the 16th Karmapa. He has officially recognized Trinlay Thaye Dorje as the 17th Gyalwa Karmapa. Shamarpa spends most of his time teaching, travelling around the world.<ref name="DWBT"/>
He is the founder of [[Bodhi Path]], another Karma Kagyu Buddhist group.<ref>[http://www.bodhipath.org/about/ Bodhi Path homepage] Retrieved on 2009-02-02</ref>
===Lopon Tsechu Rinpoche=== {{Main|Lopon Tsechu Rinpoche}} Lopon Tsechu Rinpoche (1918–2003) was the first teacher of Hannah and Ole Nydahl. He was born in [[Bhutan]], but left the country when he was 13 in order to study and practice Buddhism in [[Nepal]]. He met the 16th Karmapa in 1944 and the Karmapa became his most important teacher. He visited Europe for the first time in 1987 at the invitation of the Nydahls, who were his first Western students. He traveled extensively throughout Europe, the Americas, and Australia giving teachings and initiations. He completed 17 [[stupa]]s (Buddhist monuments) in Europe and Asia, including two important stupas in [[Spain]]: A [[Kalachakra stupa]] and the [[Benalmádena Stupa]],<ref name="DWBT"/> the biggest stupa outside Asia.<ref>[http://www.stupabenalmadena.org/en/introduction_en.html StupaBenalmadena.org] Retrieved on 2009-02-02</ref>
===Sherab Gyaltsen Rinpoche=== Maniwa Sherab Gyaltsen Rinpoche (born 1950), in Nepal. He was ordained in [[Rumtek]] by the 16th Karmapa. The title "[[Maniwa]]" is a title given to a master of the [[Chenrezig]] practice, who have accomplished a billion ''[[Om mani peme hung]]'' [[mantras]].{{citation needed|date=November 2010}} {{clear}}
===Other lamas=== Other teachers mentioned as teachers by DiamondWay-Buddhism.org:<ref name="DWBT"/> * [[Jigme Rinpoche]] * [[Shangpa Rinpoche]]
